title: Controlling P–C/C–H Bond Cleavage in Nickel Bis(diphosphine) Complexes: Reactivity Scope, Mechanism, and Computations

reactions.text: Cleavage of P–C bonds has been reported in reactions of metal complexes with P2N2 ligands (P2N2 = 1,5-diaza-3,7-diphosphacyclooctane with alkyl/aryl groups on the P and N). Mock and co-workers found that macrocyclic P3N3 and P4N4 chromium complexes formed from CrCl2(THF) and P2N2. Heterolytic cleavage of an α-C(sp3)–H bond by a binuclear [FeFe]-dithiolate complex was observed by Wang, Hall, and co-workers. Cleavage of α-C–H bonds of phosphine ligands has been reported in redox reactions of mononuclear Fe diphosphine complexes. Deprotonation of α-C–H bonds by base in Ni complexes has been reported, particularly in the formation of pincer ligands.

The violet color observed during the reaction suggests that the heteroleptic complex 2a might have been formed initially, followed by rapid ligand redistribution to form the homoleptic complex. The reaction of 1 with dppe in nitromethane immediately generated a violet solution, and the solution turned red within 10 min. The product of P–C bond cleavage, 3a, was isolated in 62% yield and was characterized by X-ray crystallography and NMR spectroscopy. The violet solution is presumed to be the heteroleptic Ni complex 2a.

The violet color observed during the reaction suggests that the heteroleptic complex 2a might have been formed initially, followed by rapid ligand redistribution to form the homoleptic complex. The reaction of 1 with dppe in nitromethane immediately generated a violet solution, and the solution turned red within 10 min. The product of P–C bond cleavage, 3a, was isolated in 62% yield and was characterized by X-ray crystallography and NMR spectroscopy. The violet solution is presumed to be the heteroleptic Ni complex 2a.

To examine the effect of the length of the diphosphine linker on the stability of the heteroleptic Ni complex 2 and the P–C/C–H bond cleavage reactivity, we prepared complex 2b, which contains dmpm, a diphosphine ligand with a C1 linker and thereby a small bite angle. The dark green complex 2b was readily synthesized from 1 and dmpm in acetonitrile and isolated as a pure solid. The 31P{1H} NMR spectrum of 2b in acetonitrile solution shows triplets at 11.8 and −59.4 ppm assigned to the phosphorus nuclei of P2N2 and dmpm, respectively. The X-ray crystal structure of 2b showed a pentacoordinate geometry similar to that of 2d, with one phosphine of the P2N2 ligand residing at the axial position of the distorted square pyramid and one bound acetonitrile at the equatorial position (Figure 3).

Alternatively, [Ni(PtBu2NBn2)(dmpm)(CH3CN)]2+[BF4–]2 could be synthesized from dmpm, PtBu2NBn2 ,and [Ni(CH3CN)6]2+[BF4–]2 in one pot. Bis(dimethylphosphino)methane (dmpm, 27.2 mg, 0.2 mmol) and PtBu2NBn2 (88.4 mg, 0.2 mmol) were added to a suspension of [Ni(CH3CN)6]2+[BF4–]2 (96.0 mg, 0.2 mmol) in CH2Cl2 (3 mL) at room temperature.
